#neurotwitter

item.title:
üí°Forming linking groups works best when collaboration takes place before submitting a request.
Use #SfN23 to connect with others in your research area. Then, use the "Linking Groups" function in the abstract submission system to create or join a group.

item.title: üí°Review the Special Linking Group Report within the abstract submission site that lists all linking groups that have been created by abstract submitters for groups related to your research that you may be interested in joining.

item.title:
üí°Make sure all abstracts in a group select the same theme and topic and presentation preference for group consideration!
If these fields are marked differently, the abstract will likely be sessioned apart from the group.

item.title: @PessoaBrain @tyrell_turing @KordingLab To what extent blood flow is a good proxy there? I understood they modeled the neuro-vascular response but I couldn't wrap my head around how the vascular global geometry would impact such patterns. In other words, what are the geometrical constraints on global blood flows ?
item.description: @PessoaBrain @tyrell_turing @KordingLab To what extent blood flow is a good proxy there? I understood they modeled the neuro-vascular response but I couldn't wrap my head around how the vascular global geometry would impact such patterns. In other words, what are the geometrical constraints on global blood flows ?
item.content:encoded: @PessoaBrain @tyrell_turing @KordingLab To what extent blood flow is a good proxy there? I understood they modeled the neuro-vascular response but I couldn't wrap my head around how the vascular global geometry would impact such patterns. In other words, what are the geometrical constraints on global blood flows ?

item.title:
@PessoaBrain @KordingLab Really?!? I'm not saying you're wrong, I'm just surprised.
Is it that the specialization and functional connectivity stuff gets over-interpreted, i.e. the "prevailing view" is that tiny little bits of brain light up and then light up the other little bits they're connected to?

item.title: I've been pondering behavior a fair bit. What are examples of rapid animal learning? I'm looking for behaviors that aren't innate but are learned quickly (e.g. way less time than it takes to learn to make decisions at psychophysical threshold). Foraging would fit- what else?
